p: The broadband decoupled 13C NMR spectrum of purpurin exhibited carbonyl carbon peaks at around δ 181 and 188 ppm and the carbon attached to hydroxyl group appeared at δ 150, 158 and 161 ppm. Depending on the extent of lithiation, the carbonyl carbons displayed slight upfield shifts, whereas the aromatic carbons attached to the hydroxyl group exhibited downfield shifts ( Figure S2). Figure 4a–d display the overlayed 13C-DEPT-135 spectra of pristine purpurin, ELP-1, ELP-2 and CLP, where only the proton bearing carbons are detected. Strikingly, the C d carbon shifted upfield from 110.3 ppm in pure purpurin to 104.4 ppm, depending on the extent of lithiation process. In addition, the observations from 1H and 13C NMR are further supported by 7Li NMR as shown in Figure S3.
